coverageText:
Ay, woe betide the heart that withers fast   
In coils of bitter rue, where shadows cast—  
A soul entrapped by time’s relentless breath,  
Hath sorrow traced upon this brow, ’tis death.  

What folly mine, to tread along yon path,  
Where fate’s cruel jest unmasked its wrath.  
Methinks the hours lost, like sand through glass,  
In search of dreams too fleet, too soon to pass.  

O conscience, art thou specter of my night?  
Thou bring’st the past with burdened wings alight.  
Each choice a dagger sharp, doth pierce my breast,  
Yet cannot slake the thirst for hopeful rest.  

What deeds undone doth round upon the stage  
And clamor loud with ever-righteous rage?  
Oft have I turned and sought with tearful eye  
The moments fled, and asked for reason why.  

O muse of respite, grant thy voice to me,  
To silence echoes of my heart’s decree,  
Let yonder morn bring solace to my soul,  
And cast anew my fate in light’s control.  

For, in this breath, I ponder deeply still,  
If by regret’s hand, I might learn free will—  
To stave my grief, to mend this weary heart,  
Before the curtain falls and we must part.  

Thus do I stand, alone amidst the night,  
And yearn for dawn to quell its endless fright.  
Yet here remains imprisoned, 'neath the stars,  
My soul entwined, regret its cruelest bars.
